G.L. c. 212, \\u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, or, alternatively, because Plaintiff, in good faith, seeks damages within the jurisdictional authority of the Superior Court.

G.L. c. 223A, \\u00a7 3(a).proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant because he is domiciled in Massachusetts and all acts and omissions alleged herein occurred within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 223A, § 3(a).

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, because the events and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts, and both parties reside in Hampden County.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care toward others in the circumstances so as to avoid causing foreseeable harm.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly states as a general principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, and ties the existence of that duty to the recognizability or foreseeability of the risk of harm. The opinion then applies that general principle to hold that the homeowner owed a duty of reasonable care because the harm to the officer was a foreseeable consequence of her conduct. This aligns directly with the proposition that, under Massachusetts law, one owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others in the circumstances.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor."

*Remy v. MacDonald*, 440 Mass. 675, 677\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care toward others in the circumstances so as to avoid causing foreseeable harm.
*Remy v. MacDonald*, 440 Mass. 675, 677\.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the general principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, citing the Restatement. Although the case ultimately recognizes an exception in the specific context of a pregnant woman’s duty to her fetus, it clearly affirms the broad Massachusetts tort principle of a general duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable physical harm.
*Remy v. MacDonald*, 440 Mass. 675, 677\.relevant_excerpt: As a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 302 comment a (1965) ("In general, anyone who does an affirmative act is under a duty to others to exercise the care of a reasonable man to protect them against an unreasonable risk of harm to them arising out of the act").

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Negligence under Massachusetts law consists of (a) a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (b) breach of that duty; (c) causation; and (d) actual damages.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the elements the plaintiffs must prove on their negligence claims under Massachusetts law. It identifies (1) breach of a duty to use reasonable care, (2) actual loss (damages), and (3) causation as required elements, while duty is explicitly referenced as something the plaintiffs must show and that the judge analyzed. Together this tracks the standard four-element formulation of negligence: duty, breach, causation, and damages.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law governing property-related negligence, one who controls or stores items on premises in a manner that may foreseeably cause injury to others using the area must exercise reasonable care.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on causation and foreseeability in the context of campus security (guards, locked gates, dorm/refectory access), not on the duty of one who controls or stores items on premises. It does discuss foreseeability of harm from an inadequately secured gate or unlocked refectory, but that is about premises security, not control or storage of items creating a risk to others using the area. Thus it does not establish or articulate the specific property-related negligence principle stated in the proposition.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes."

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law governing property-related negligence, one who controls or stores items on premises in a manner that may foreseeably cause injury to others using the area must exercise reasonable care.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses a Massachusetts landowner’s common-law duty regarding dangerous conditions and expressly holds that a possessor who creates and maintains a hazardous arrangement on the premises must exercise reasonable care, including a duty to remedy the condition when it is foreseeable that lawful entrants will encounter it. The court emphasizes that the duty extends even to open and obvious dangers where the defendant can or should anticipate harm, precisely in a context where the defendants stored/arranged recreational items (trampoline and pool) in a foreseeably dangerous manner. This aligns with the proposition that one who controls or stores items on premises in a manner foreseeably causing injury must use reasonable care.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … ‘[A] landowner is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ … Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool…for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool.”

G.L. c. 231, \\u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s duty of reasonable care is consistent with the general principles embodied in G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence statute), which presupposes the existence of a duty and standard of reasonable care in negligence actions.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that where a defendant is specifically alerted to a hazardous condition and fails to remedy it, such inaction constitutes evidence of negligence.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation rule for snow and ice and adopting a general reasonable-care standard for premises liability. It discusses notice in the sense of an owner knowing or having reason to know of a dangerous condition, but it does not specifically address a defendant being ‘specifically alerted’ to a particular hazard and then failing to remedy it as distinct evidence of negligence. The case therefore does not establish the more specific proposition claimed; it only supports the broader duty-of-reasonable-care principle tied to knowledge of a dangerous condition.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that where a defendant is specifically alerted to a hazardous condition and fails to remedy it, such inaction constitutes evidence of negligence.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.support_reasoning: The excerpt addresses duty and foreseeability, concluding that there is no duty to warn of an inherent and obvious risk at a self-service (or mini-serve) gas station. It does not discuss a defendant being specifically alerted to a hazardous condition or failing to remedy it, nor does it treat such inaction as evidence of negligence. Thus, the case as quoted does not establish or affirm the proposition claimed.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.relevant_excerpt: "In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger."

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640–641 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take simple, inexpensive, and obvious precautions—after being expressly warned—falls below the standard of care required under Massachusetts negligence law.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: This concurrence addresses causation and foreseeability, not whether failure to take simple, inexpensive, obvious precautions after express warning falls below the standard of care. Justice Lynch expressly focuses on whether the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm, and does not discuss or establish a rule about inexpensive or obvious precautions post‑warning. Thus, this opinion does not provide authority for the specific negligence standard claimed in the proposition.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.proposition: "Cause in fact" (factual causation) exists where the harm would not have occurred "but for" the defendant’s negligent conduct, and "proximate cause" exists where the harm is a foreseeable result of the conduct.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly distinguishes between cause in fact and proximate (legal) cause and defines proximate cause in terms of foreseeability, while separately recognizing factual causation. Although it does not use the phrase “but for,” it clearly treats factual causation as the basic causal connection and then explains that proximate cause is a further limitation based on foreseeability and policy. This aligns with the proposition that factual causation is a “but for” inquiry and proximate cause turns on foreseeability.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.relevant_excerpt: “‘[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff.’ … In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. … Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. … In this respect, proximate cause prevents liability from being based on factual causation alone.”

*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 70 Mass..raw_text: *Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 641, 645–646 (2007)
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 70 Mass..proposition: "Cause in fact" (factual causation) exists where the harm would not have occurred "but for" the defendant’s negligent conduct, and "proximate cause" exists where the harm is a foreseeable result of the conduct.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 70 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is an employment contract / personnel manual case and does not analyze tort causation, "cause in fact," "but for" causation, or "proximate cause." The terms in the proposition never appear, and the court’s reasoning is confined to contract formation, modification, and breach, plus statute of limitations and damages. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the stated causation proposition.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 70 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that a contract action accrues at the time the contract is breached. Berkshire Mut. Ins. Co. v. Burbank, 422 Mass. 659, 661 (1996). Barber v. Fox, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 525, 527 (1994). Here, LeMaitre alleges that a breach occurred in 2002 when he retired and the authority informed him that all of his accrued sick time would be paid in accordance with the terms of its 1996 incentive program.”

*Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst.*, 443.proposition: Although Plaintiff did not suffer bodily injury and incurred approximately $0 in medical bills and $0 in lost wages, Massachusetts law permits recovery for property damage, loss of use, and related economic losses resulting from negligence.
*Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst.*, 443.support_reasoning: The opinion is a complex employment, retaliation, defamation, and peer-review-privilege case; it does not address ordinary negligence causing property damage, loss of use, or purely economic losses. The damages discussion concerns emotional distress, reputational and economic harm from employment-related and defamation claims, not negligence without bodily injury, medical expenses, or wage loss. Nothing in the decision articulates a rule about recovery for property damage and related economic losses in a negligence action with no bodily injury, so it does not support the stated proposition.
*Ayash v. Dana-Farber Cancer Inst.*, 443.relevant_excerpt: “The jury awarded damages against Dana-Farber in the amount of $180,000 for lost compensation and injury to business reputation, $1,080,000 for emotional distress… For the plaintiff’s defaulted claims against the Globe defendants, the jury awarded her the sum of $1,680,000 against the Globe (reflecting $240,000 in economic damages and $1,440,000 in emotional distress damages)… [T]he only damages to which the plaintiff is entitled are for economic losses suffered as a result of the hospital’s failure to provide written notice of her right to a hearing.”

*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..proposition: Although Plaintiff did not suffer bodily injury and incurred approximately $0 in medical bills and $0 in lost wages, Massachusetts law permits recovery for property damage, loss of use, and related economic losses resulting from negligence.
*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion involves a plaintiff who clearly suffered serious bodily injury (a crushed hand) and obtained a $100,000 jury award for those personal injuries. The court’s discussion centers on negligence, breach of warranty, and Chapter 93A liability, not on recovery where there is no bodily injury or for purely property/economic losses. Nothing in the cited pages (or the opinion generally) addresses the availability of damages when there are $0 medical bills, $0 lost wages, or only property damage/loss-of-use; thus it does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that ‘the defendant breached its warranty of merchantability in that it failed to warn of dangerous conditions. The machine in its condition was not of merchantable quality. As a result, [the] plaintiff’s hand became caught and crushed by the machine . . . .’… The judge also took notice of the jury’s conclusion that the defendant was negligent. These findings yield ample factual support for the judge’s holding that the defendant had violated G. L. c. 93A, § 2.”

G.L. c. 231, \\u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre- and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in actions for damage to property).

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7\u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Plaintiff also seeks taxable costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 et seq., and any other relief the Court deems just and proper.

G.L. c. 231, \\u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable rules, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
